descriptionSet.description: An image with the title "Friends" in a sample calender poster of the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co., Calcutta depicting two women sitting on a couch and chatting while drinking tea. The side table holds a white ceramic tea set with containers for tea, milk and sugar. Both of them hold steaming cups of tea in tea cups with saucers in their hands. In the background, the lower part of an image with a European-style landscape can be seen on the wall.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: TCM [publisher's signet]
No.411 FRIENDS

description-en: An image with the title "Friends" in a sample calender poster of the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co., Calcutta depicting two women sitting on a couch and chatting while drinking tea. The side table holds a white ceramic tea set with containers for tea, milk and sugar. Both of them hold steaming cups of tea in tea cups with saucers in their hands. In the background, the lower part of an image with a European-style landscape can be seen on the wall. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Social spaces and practices, that now appear to be as quintessentially Indian as rice and dal, in fact spread through much of north and central India only during the last four decades of the twentieth century—thus, no retail bulk-tea supplier in Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan, predates the late 1960s, because, as one shopkeeper there told me, "People didn't drink much tea here before that." (Philip Lutgendorf) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: As the first mass marketed food product in South Asia, tea and its indigenized avatar chai is thus not merely an energizing and comforting drink: it is a potent (kaṛak!) signifier of many of the historical and social transformations of the past century: the spread of urbanization, mass transportation, capitalism, nationalism, and of changing lifestyles, caste practices, and gender roles. Visual texts, such as the images in the Priya Paul collection, are an important source for documenting the impact of these changes on everyday life, and I hope to use many more in my continuing research on the social and cultural history of chai. (Philip Lutgendorf) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: New practices enable new relations, such as Valentine's Greeting cards enable a new language and fabric of what romantic love could be like, and provides for new spaces of consumption and display of these relations: this image, too, speaks of the relationship of friendship between women who have consciously chosen to spend their leisure time together, and chat - and make it part of a performance, of distinction. They know that tea is a 'new trend' and cherish this knowledge. This might also underline discussions about how new consumption trends enforce new social relations. (cb)
